file_metadata.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]
file_metadata.title: BioDome Regenerative Sleeve for Biochemical and Biophysical Stimulation of Tissue Regeneration

chunks.text: Tissue regeneration, unlike typical wound healing, involves rebuilding all original structures. While mammals have limited regenerative abilities, some organisms exhibit epimorphic regeneration, replacing lost structures with replicas. Three requirements for epimorphic regeneration are mitotically active cells, signals promoting cell proliferation, and the absence of inhibitory factors like dry environments or infections.
chunks.chunk_summary: Epimorphic regeneration, unlike wound healing, rebuilds all original structures and requires specific conditions.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: In mammalian wound healing, a fibrin clot forms, containing various growth factors. Re-epithelialization occurs as epidermal cells migrate, digesting the clot's basement layer. Moist wounds accelerate re-epithelialization. Scar tissue, lacking original tissue function, forms with a dense collagen network. Wound epithelium formation is necessary for regeneration, as shown by studies where forced wound closure halted regeneration in human fingertips and amphibians.
chunks.chunk_summary: Mammalian wound healing involves clot formation, re-epithelialization, and scar tissue development, while wound epithelium is crucial for regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Regeneration can be seen as a deviation from wound healing, involving biophysical responses like cellular membrane depolarization and electric fields. These bioelectric phenomena, more pronounced in regeneration, guide innervation and cell migration. This study aimed to develop the "BioDome," a device creating a controlled environment around a wound to stimulate regeneration, reduce scarring, and promote faster tissue regeneration in amputated murine digits.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BioDome aims to stimulate regeneration by controlling the wound environment, including bioelectric factors.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Regenerative systems require new cells, often sourced from dedifferentiated local cells forming a blastema. This blastema, crucial for amphibian limb regeneration, differentiates into various tissues. Electrical stimulation in the BioDome mimics biophysical regeneration processes, replicating stump currents observed in amphibians. Previous studies showed enhanced regeneration with electrical stimulation, but this study combines it with a controlled environment and pharmacological cocktails.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BioDome uses electrical stimulation, mimicking natural bioelectric processes, to promote blastema formation and cell differentiation.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: This 14-day study examined the combined effects of porcine urinary bladder matrix (UBM) pepsin digest and electrical stimulation. UBM digest increases regeneration, while altering transmembrane potential can trigger cell dedifferentiation or mitosis. Depolarization, observed in regenerating cells, is a potential mechanism for stimulating regeneration. This study combines the BioDome's controlled environment with electrical stimulation and pharmacological cocktails to explore regeneration potential.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the combined effects of UBM, electrical stimulation, and a controlled environment on digit regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The BioDome consists of a polyimide cuff, silicone septum, nylon reservoir, and stainless steel cathode. Different cuff sizes accommodate varying digit sizes. The nylon reservoir holds the treatment, and the silicone septum allows access. The stainless steel cathode maximizes contact area with the wound. Sterilization is done with ethylene oxide gas. VetBond secures the BioDome to the digit, creating a watertight seal.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BioDome is designed to provide a controlled, sterile environment for wound treatment and electrical stimulation.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The study used male C57BL/6 mice, aged 6-8 weeks. Anesthesia was administered via Ketamine and Xylazine. The right hind middle digit was amputated at the second phalange midline. Two treatment groups (n=6 each) were used: Group 1 received UBM digest control, and Group 2 received UBM digest with electrical stimulation. Control data included untreated digits and BioDome with/without electrical stimulation. UBM treatments, prepared from porcine urinary bladder ECM, act as scaffolds for cell growth.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study used male mice, amputated digits, and two treatment groups involving UBM with and without electrical stimulation, along with various controls.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: ECM digest treatments were delivered via hypodermic syringes through the BioDome septum. Electrical stimulation (6.4 Î¼A for 15 minutes) was applied on days 0, 1, and 3 via a subcutaneous anode in the haunch and the BioDome cathode. Current flow was verified with an ammeter. Post-surgery, mice received buprenorphine and were housed individually with free access to food and water. On day 14, amputated digits and adjacent control digits were collected for histological analysis.
chunks.chunk_summary: Treatments were delivered via the BioDome, electrical stimulation was applied for 15 minutes on days 0, 1, and 3, and post-operative care included pain management and individual housing.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The BioDomes were well-tolerated, maintaining a controlled environment. Installation took approximately 10 minutes per subject. Devices remained attached for up to 6 days. Untreated digits showed typical wound healing with thin epithelium, scar tissue, and LMECs. BioDome-only treatment showed minimal regrowth. Electrical stimulation with BioDome (no treatment) showed advanced regrowth with thick epithelium and organized LMECs.
chunks.chunk_summary: BioDomes were well-tolerated and effective in maintaining a controlled environment, while electrical stimulation showed enhanced regrowth compared to controls.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: UBM control with electrical stimulation showed thicker epithelia, collagen deposition, bone remodeling, LMECs, and hair follicles. UBM treatment with electrical stimulation showed highly organized LMECs, bone remodeling, thick epithelia with hair follicles, and large regrowth regions. Bone remodeling was asymmetrical in all subjects.  These results suggest that both the BioDome and electrical stimulation contribute to enhanced regeneration, with UBM treatment further promoting these effects.
chunks.chunk_summary: UBM treatment combined with electrical stimulation showed the most significant regenerative effects, including thicker epithelia, bone remodeling, and hair follicle redevelopment.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The BioDome addresses wound hydration, drug delivery, electrical stimulation, and subject management. It prevents dehydration and contamination, allows drug administration, and incorporates electrical stimulation.  This study aimed to develop a device controlling microenvironmental conditions at the wound site, particularly relevant for limb loss injuries. The BioDome's materials and design minimize damage from subject interaction and environmental exposure.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BioDome's design addresses key challenges in wound healing and regeneration by controlling the microenvironment and facilitating treatment delivery.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Previous devices delivered either electrical stimulation or pharmacological treatment, but the BioDome combines both with a simple installation.  The BioDome's use of stainless steel acupuncture needles as the anode proved effective. The device enhanced regeneration even without stimulation or treatment, with further enhancement observed upon their application.  Future investigations will address design flaws like minimal digit necrosis and short adhesion time.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BioDome combines electrical and pharmacological treatment delivery in a simple design, showing enhanced regeneration even without these interventions, but requires further refinement.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The small reservoir volume requires modification due to contamination by biological fluids. While an external system is possible for larger animals, increasing the reservoir size and frequent replenishment are more realistic for murine studies. The study concludes that the BioDome's hydrated environment and electrical stimulation enhance digit regeneration, with UBM treatment further promoting these effects. Future studies will focus on increasing reservoir volume and minimizing digit irritation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Future BioDome designs will address limitations like small reservoir volume and digit irritation to further enhance regenerative capabilities.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The BioDome's hydrated environment and electrical stimulation significantly enhance digit regeneration, with UBM treatment showing further improvement.  These preliminary results are promising, but future design modifications are needed to optimize reservoir volume and minimize digit irritation.  The study demonstrates the potential of combining a controlled microenvironment, electrical stimulation, and pharmacological treatment for promoting regeneration in a murine model.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BioDome system shows promise for enhancing digit regeneration through a combination of controlled environment, electrical stimulation, and UBM treatment, but further optimization is needed.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: This study acknowledges contributions from various individuals and institutions, including Tufts University, University of Massachusetts Lowell, and funding support from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and the Defense Advanced Research Project Agency (DARPA).
chunks.chunk_summary: The study acknowledges contributions from individuals and funding support from NIH and DARPA.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The list of abbreviations defines terms used in the paper, including ECM (Extracellular matrix), EGF (Epidermal growth factor), GAG (Glycosaminoglycan), HP-EGF (Heparin-binding epidermal growth factor), LMEC (Large mononuclear eosinophilic cell), MMP (Matrix metalloproteinase), TGF-a (Transforming growth factor a), and UBM ((porcine) urinary bladder matrix).
chunks.chunk_summary: The list provides definitions for abbreviations used throughout the study, clarifying terminology related to extracellular matrix components, growth factors, and cell types.
chunks.authors: ["Daniel Hechvarria", "Abiche Dewilde", "Susan Braunhut", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]
